phrase.item: When a person falls ill the neighbors go to ask [after his health].
When he dies, at the moment of his death they tie his jaw and lay him out on the main platform, the long side.
Everyone who comes in cries and wails.
Then some men go to dig a grave.

When the grave is almost ready they prepare burial clothes. For a man, pants; for a woman, pojdʒoma. For a man, a shirt; for a woman, a dress. For a man, a turban; for a woman, a kerchief. For both men and women they make a large shroud.
First, both men and women are splashed with holy water; then they [the others] wash them and dry them with a cloth so that the [burial] clothes won't stick to the body.
Then they dress him in the burial clothes; the clothing is sewn on but not properly.
When they put it on, they say: "He is in his traveling clothes."
The shroud for a infant is in the form of a sack, and they put him in the sack.
If [the child] is more than one year old, one follows the local custom.
They make a litter (or a ladder, or they attach some wood).
They put him on a stretcher.
They lift up the dead body and take him out, because the litter won't fit in the door.
They take him out head-first and put a nail in the threshold and close up the chimney.
They place him on the litter, take seven steps, and then place him [on the ground]. The old men arrange themselves in four rows, then they put in front of them fabric, horses, and cows.
The mullah or caliph will pray for the soul of the dead.
After this, all the fabric will be given to the mullah, whatever they had put for the dead.
When they bring him to the tomb, one person goes into the tomb with him.

He turns his face to the Qiblah side, uncovers his face, and puts the turban or kerchief next to him. Right after a death the dead person's hands are placed under his bottom and when they put him in the grave, [the person there with him] takes them out from under his bottom and puts his hands at his sides.
He puts stones in his hands.
When the work inside the grave is done, the person who put him there comes out and the relatives of the dead come to look.
Then on top of the grave they put a flat stone, prepare a coating to spread on top, and decorate the grave.
They make the grave like a trunk, so that the dirt doesn't cause it to cave in.
Then each relative comes and one at a time puts a shovel of earth [in the grave], then the epitaph is inscribed and at that time a mullah reads some verses.
When return from from there and enter the house, a mullah again recites some verses.
In one of the neighbor's houses they prepare food and bring it to the house of the mourners. The guests who are staying there are served that food.
In the house of the mourners no fire is lit until the funeral meal.

That evening the storytellers sing hymns [ruboi]; the night of a dead person's burial, one person from each neighboring house will go to sleep there--this [custom] is called "shabi nexest" [first night].
The next day in the morning the neighbors bring food, which is called "noni sharii."
When it is finished, the head of the household will hold a funeral meal--he slaughters a cow or sheep and makes bat [a dish of flour and oil] with the meat.
They give some to all the neighbors and they say the takbir.
After takbir they bring sheep and wheat.
The sheep is brought alive to the house.
The mullah says a prayer
and the sheep is slaughtered.
They grind the wheat.
Then then they cook it together with the mutton. If there is any boch [stew] left over, they will throw it somewhere in a clean place.
On the eve of any festival, for example Ramadan or Kurban [Eid al-Adha], the family of the dead person must hold a memorial feast and make "bat" for Ramadan.
Every Friday morning women go to the grave to cry and sing hymns [ruboi].
Ruboi are often about love.
But the ones [they sing] are about sorrow. For example: "Oh me, oh me, you have destroyed me, in a raging fire you have roasted me."
"[But] in such a raging fire no kebab would be cooked."
"I was a stone and you have melted me."
"You were a schoolboy!"
"Your books are abandoned!"
"You were a good farmer, you have left your children hungry!"
When a young or beloved person dies, his close relatives, when they enter, scratch at their faces, pull their hair, and undo their braids.
They go so far as to claw at their chests and cut off their hair.
For [someone less than] four months old no chirog [lighting] ceremony is held; they organize a delilek ["guide"], dip a wick in oil, and light it on top of a [stick of] wood.
Prayers are recited, and no type of food besides osh may be served, the "osh xedoyi." [A type of soup.]
